question: Elapidaes are-
exp: Elapidaes are Neurotoxic Elapidaeare a family of venomous snakes commonly referred to as elapids. This family includes cobras, adders, mambas, common kraits....................................................................................................................................................................................... VIPERIDAE are vasculotoxic/hemotoxic. This framily includes russel viper and saw scaled viper...................................................................................................................................................................................... Hydropidae are myotoxic and this family includes sea snakes.

question: The toxic principle of this plant is:-
exp: Mayapple (May Apple) Toxic Principle: Podophyllin (purified form: podophyllotoxin) Clinical Features: Exposure of eyes causes irritation with conjunctivitis, keratitis, corneal ulceration, and iritis. Ingestion results in nausea, abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhoea. fever, tachypnoea, tachycardia, hypotension, ataxia, dizziness, lethargy, confusion, and altered sensorium. Treatment: No specific antidote is known. Emesis may be useful during the initial phases of toxicity. Hemodialysis is ineffective, but charcoal hemoperfusion has reversed acute symptoms within hours. Topically administered resin should be removed with petroleum jelly. If eye contact occurs, flush with copious amounts of warm water and consult a physician or poison center immediately.

question: Danbury tremor is seen in?
exp: Mercury poisoning:- Danbury tremor is a classical and consistent manifestation of mercury poisoning. Coarse intentional tremor interspersed with jerky movements. It begins in the hand and progresses to lips, tongue, arms and legs.

question: Sudomotor neuropathy in poisoning:-
exp: Mnemonic Arsenic poisoning A - Anemia / Aldrich Mee's line / Arsenophagist (Tolerate upto 300mg ) R - Rain drop pigmentation / Reinsch test / Red velvety mucosa S - Sub endocardial hemorrhages / Sensory neuropathy E - Eruptions N - NAA I - Imbibition of arsenic ( Arsenic imbibed from surrounding soils after death ) / before treated iron oxide C - Cumulative poison / Cholera like symptom / Chelation for treatment

question: In corrosive acid case is opened along:
exp: In corrosive acid poisoning, it is open along the greater curvature. Toxic substances may be held in high concentrations in the rugae and crypts of the mucosa in the actual stomach wall. The pathway of acids and alkalis in food-filled stomach stas along the lesser curvature of the stomach and leads to the pylorus, which explains the location of greatest damage in stomach.

question: Most common abused substance is:
exp: Cannabis / marijuana: Most commonly abused substance in India Opium: Derived from Papaver somniferum; poison of choice for suicide Heroin / brown sugar: Synthetic derivative of opium Datura: Roadside poison or railway poison Cocaine: Obtained from dried leaves of Erythroxylum coca

question: Which secretion is not decreased in this poisoning?
exp: the given image is papaver somniferum / opium poppy. The only body secretion that is not impaired in opium poisoning is sweat. All other secretions are decreased. Skin in opium poisoning is moist and cold (impoant to distinguish it from other poisonings) patient manifest with low Blood pressure, Slow pulse, slow respiration.

question: The following plant contains the toxic substance-
exp: The plant is Indian spinach, which contains oxalic acid(image given) oxalic acid --> stomach-->blood-->Hypocalcemia Treatment is IV calcium.

question: The active principle of this toxic seed is:
exp: The given image is castor seed also known as Ricinus communis. Crushed seed is poisonous. It contains active principle- Ricin which leads to intense gastroenteritis and bloody diarrhoea.

question: Necrosis of A is seen in all except:
exp: The image shows PCT necrosis: PCT Necrosis C- CCl4, Cadmium A- Acids ( oxalic acid, Carbolic acid) L- Lysol M- Mercury

question: The following is true regarding this snake except?
exp: The picture shows diamond shaped marks one on the top and two on the sides. It is Russel viper so it contains hemotoxic venom so first option is wrong. Indian anti venom snake is effective against common cobra, Krait, Russel viper and saw scaled viper. So 2nd option is true. Viper is viviparous as it gives bih to young ones. DIC is a common manifestation and also causes renal failure.
opb: Indian Antisnake venom is effective in this bite

exp: POISONS STOMACH MUCOSA Carbolic acid Leathery mucosa Sulphuric acid Black necrotic stomach mucosa Arsenic Red velvety Mucosa Mercury Slate gray Mucosa HNO3 Yellowish Sodium amytal, Copper sulfate Blue

question: Gastric lavage is contraindicated in all the following poisonings except:-
exp: Gastric lavage is absolutely contraindicated in following condition Corrosive (except phenol which thickens the membrane and maintains leathery consistency so gastric lavage can be done) Convulsant patient Comatose patient Kerosene poisoning

question: Tensilon test is used for?
exp: TENSILON TEST: edrophonium is used to differentiate botulism from myasthenia gravis. Botulism Tensilon test Arsenic Marsh Test Iron Desferrioxamine colour test Phenol Ferric chloride test

question: Which of the following order is true about toxicity of mercury
exp: There are 3 forms of mercury:- 1. Organic - most toxic 2. Mercuric- intermediate 3. Mercurous -least toxic
opa: Organic salts > mercuric salts> mercurous salts
opb: Mercuric salts> organic salts> mercurous salts
opc: Mercuric salts > mercurous salts> organic salts
opd: Mercurous salts > organic salts> mercuric salts

question: All are true about this poison except:-
exp: Fruit is thorn apple of datura plant. Every pa of this plant is poisonous but highest concentration is found in roots & seeds. It has two active principle hyoscine and atropine. Major active principle is hyoscine. Muttering delirium is seen in datura poisoning where as excited delirium in cocaine. It causes anti- cholinergic effects (parasympatholytic effects).
opa: Highest concentration is found in root

question: The sample taken below is sent for biochemical analysis in?
exp: The sample taken in image is Vitreous sample. A preservative Potassium/sodium fluoride 0. 5-2%w/v is used for Collecting vitreous humour sample for ethanol analysis in postmoem toxicology cases.

question: The following is the symptom in:
exp: Aldrich mees line: White bands of opacity in nails of fingers and toes Mees lines (horizontal 1 to 2 mm white lines on the nails, also called transverse leukonychia) which occur from a disturbance in the nail matrix keratinization. Note: It usually takes at least 30 days for the Mees lines to become visible. It may be seen 4 to 6 weeks after an acute arsenic ingestion. These can also be seen in Thallium poisoning and Chemotherapy.

question: Rain drop pigmentation is seen in:-
exp: * Arsenic poisoning A Anemia / Aldrich mee's line / Arsenophagist (Tolerate up to 300mg)R Rain drop pigmentation / Reinsch test / Red velvety mucosa S Sub endocardial hemorrhages / Sensory neuropathy E EruptionsN NAA (neutron activation analysis)I Imbibition of arsenic (Arsenic imbibed from surrounding soils after death)C Cumulative poison / Cholera like symptom / Chelation for Rx * Phosphors poisoning - 4 'P'P - Protoplasmic poison P - Phossy jaw (lucifer's jaw) P - Photo luminescent P - Purpura * Mercury poisoningS - Strawberry tongue L - Mercuria lentisA - Acrodynia T - Tremor E - Erythism Grey - Glass blower's shake Mucosa - Minamata disease.

question: Hairs are preserved in which poisoning:-
exp: Poison Organ preserved Nux vomica Aconite Alcohol / any cerebral poison Metal (chronic) - arsenic, antimony, thallium Volatile poisoning (gas) - Spinal cord/ - Hea - Brain - Bone, hair, nail - Lungs

question: Which of the following is not true about mercuria lenits?
exp: Deposition of mercury in lens (anterior pa) is mercuria lentis. This is due to inorganic mercury.. Only Minamata's disease is associated with organic Hg. It is bilateral Visual acuity is normal & malt brown reflex is present. Mercuria lentis is due to vapours of Hg.

question: The preservative of choice in this poisoning:
exp: The most commonly used preservative for viscera is saturated solution of common salt (Na. Cl) because It is easily available, cheap and effective preservative. However, the best preservative for preservation of viscera is rectified spirit. z In cases of suspected alkali or acid poisoning (except carbolic acid), only rectified spirit is used.

question: Lead poisoning is characterized by
exp: Plumbism Features ABCDEFGHI A - Anemia B - Buonian line/Basophilic stippling, Bone lines C - Colic, Constipation (dry belly ache) D - Drop (wrist/Foot drop) - Lead palsy E - Encephalopathy F - Facial pallor (earliest sign) G - Gout (saturnine gout) H - Hypertension I - Impotence

question: Critical Level of alcohol in blood above which there is impairment in driving?
exp: Acute alcohol Poisoning Stages: 1. Excitement -> 50-150mg% 2. Incoordination-->150-250mg% 3. Coma-->>300mg% Permissible level of blood alcohol for driving in India = 30mg% Effect mg% Percentage <0. 03% less than 30 Not noticeable 0. 03%-0. 05% 30-50 Selective impairment 0. 05%-0. 10% 50-100 Slight impairment 0. 10%-0. 15% 100-150 Under the influence 0. 15%-0. 20% 150-200 Drunk 0. 20%-0. 30% 200-300 Very drunk 0. 30%-0. 35% 300-350 Stupor to coma over 0. 35% over 350 Comatose to death
